activities.title: Difference between JSON and JavaScript objects
activities.outline:
- for today's live-coding and exercises, we need some realistic, complex JavaScript objects
- we will be using the realistic [Northwind database converted to JSON files](https://github.com/graphql-compose/graphql-compose-examples/tree/master/examples/northwind/data/json)
	- each former SQL table has been converted into a JSON file
	- we will use an online tool to convert these JSON files into JavaScript objects so we can use them in a JavaScript file and execute them with Node
- the differences between JSON and JavaScript Objects
	- GOOD NEWS: **JSON is 98% JavaScript objects**
	- JavaScript created 1995, JSON created 2001
	- JSON stands for JavaScript Object Notation
	- JSON was made to transport JavaScript objects from application to application and so has a few differences in order to make the journey safe
	- **keys must be wrapped double quotation marks**
	- **string values must use double quotation marks**, not single quotation marks
	- **JSON does not allow a trailing comma**
- advantages of JSON
	- just like JavaScript objects, JSON can contain any number of levels deep of objects in arrays in arrays in objects
	- this makes JSON a very rich storage and data medium
	- JSON is arguably a reason that NoSQL became so popular and successful from 2000-2010
	- many NoSQL databases such as MongoDB use JSON as their base format to store data
	- once you know the above simple rules, using JSON is as easy as using JavaScript objects

activities.title: Closure, Recursion, Callbacks: Three Concepts Good to Know
activities.outline:
- **closure** 
	- functions inside functions carry with them their own scope
	- a way to emulate private scope
	- today use **ES6 classes**
- **recursion** 
	- functions that call themselves until a certain condition is met
	- the only way to solve [some problems](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/71166355/how-create-array-containing-all-combinations-of-array-1-n-array-items)
- **callbacks** 
	- functions that are sent as parameters into other functions
	- a central concept in functional programming
	- a very important concept to understand
	- ES6 high-order functions
	- as **non-blocking code solution**, largely replaced by JavaScript promises and **async/await**

submodules.title: 3.06 Classes
submodules.overview: Classes are a fundamental part of Object-Oriented Programming and important to understand in any programming language that supports the OOP paradigm. Since ES6, JavaScript has offered minimal functionality for structuring your code in classes. In addition to the functional programming approach, the OOP programming paradigm is a important aspect of JavaScript programming.
objectives: Understand scope and state in relation to objects and explain the this and new keywords in that context
Declare and write classes in JavaScript to produce objects of the same structure
Compare between a static class and an instance in JavaScript
Understand basic algorithm complexity and its relation to data structures

activities.title: Classes in JavaScript
activities.outline:
- real-life example: [DynamicFile](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/n49900_tech/blob/master/systemClasses/dynamicFile.js)
- 10 most important concepts of JavaScript classes
	- basics
		- 1. keyword: **class**
		- 2. **constructor**
		- 3. **methods**
		- 4. **properties**
		- 5. keyword: **this**
		- 6. **static methods**
		- 7. vocabulary: **instantiate**/**object**/**class**/**new**, e.g. "you instantiate an object with a class using the `new` keyword", "the variable `bike` is an instance of the class `Bike`"
	- inheritance
		- 8. keyword: **extends**
		- 9. keyword: **super**
		- 10. **method overriding**
- differences of JavaScript classes to classes of other languages
	- in JavaScript, a newer, added feature
		- 1995 Java - classes are core feature
		- 2001 C# - classes are core feature
		- 2005 PHP adds classes as core feature
		- 2015 JavaScript adds classes are syntactic sugar
	- Java/C#/PHP/TypeScript have more OOP robust features:
		- private/public/protected/internal
		- abstraction
		- interfaces
		- method overloading
- OOP vs. Functional programming
	- big data
		- SQL --> NoSQL
		- OOP --> functional programming
	- React: class components <-- React 16.8 (Feb 2019) --> functional components with hooks
- Why use classes?
	- they produce organized, understandable code
	- tend to eliminate duplicate code
	- they emulate objects and relationships in the world one-to-one
		- Mancala
		- FileManager
			- BinaryFileManager
				- ExcelFileManager
				- WordFileManager
			- TextFileManager
				- JsonFileManager
				- JavaScriptFileManager
				- PlainTextFileManager

flashcards.front: Name four browsers and the JavaScript Engines they use.
flashcards.back:
- **Google Chrome** uses **V8**
- **Firefox** uses **SpiderMonkey**
- **Safari** uses **JavaScriptCore**
- **Microsoft Edge** formerly used Chakra but now is based on Chromium and hence uses **V8** as Chrome does

flashcards.front: What is the difference between a tag and an element on an HTML page?
flashcards.back: Technically, an HTML **element** is the collection of its **start tag** and **end tag** and everything in between. So technically, a **tag** is used to mark the start or end of an **element**. However in common usage the terms element and tag are **often used interchangeably**.

flashcards.front: What tag do you use to add JavaScript to an HTML page?
flashcards.back: `<script>`

flashcards.front: What tag do you use to add CSS to an HTML page?
flashcards.back: `<style>`

flashcards.front: In JavaScript, what are differences between and examples of native and host objects?
flashcards.back:
- native object 
	- objects in an ECMAScript implementation whose semantics are fully defined by this specification rather than by the host environment
	- EXAMPLES: String, Math, RegExp, Object, Function
- host object
	- objects provided by the browser environment which are distinct from native objects because not all environments will have the same host objects
	- EXAMPLES IN BROWSER: `window`, `XmlHttpRequest`, `History`
	- EXAMPLES IN NODE: `http`, `https`, `fs`, `url`, `os`  
		- `const url = require('url');`
		- `const fs = require('fs');`

moreInfos.title: Stack Overflow: What is the difference between native objects and host objects?

flashcards.front: What object on the browser will 'console.log(this)' return?
flashcards.back: `Window`

flashcards.front: In a simple Node script, what will 'console.log(this)' return?
flashcards.back: `object`

moreInfos.title: Stack Overflow: Why does console.log(this) in node return an empty object?

flashcards.front: Name two ways you can get a single HTML element into a JavaScript variable?
flashcards.back:
- `document.getElementById()`
- `document.querySelector()`

flashcards.front: How can you get a numerous elements into a JavaScript variable?
flashcards.back: `document.querySelectorAll()`

flashcards.front: What does `Element.classList` do?
flashcards.back: A CSS property that returns the class names of an element, as an array-like DOMTokenList object

flashcards.front: Name two ways to add text to an HTML element?
flashcards.back:
- `Element.innerHTML`
- `Element.innerText`

flashcards.front: Name 10 examples of JavaScript events.
flashcards.back:
- `change`: An HTML element has been changed
- `click`: The user clicks an HTML element
- `mouseover`: The user moves the mouse over an HTML element or its children
- `mouseenter`: the user moves the mouse into an HTML element
- `mousemove`: The user moves the mouse inside an HTML element
- `mouseout`: The user moves the mouse away from an HTML element
- `keydown`: The user pushes a keyboard key
- `load`: The browser has finished loading the page
- `submit`: The user submits a form
- `keyup`: The user releases a key on the keyboard

flashcards.front: What does `Event.preventDefault` do?
flashcards.back:
- stops default action/behavior on the event it was called upon
- it cancels the event, meaning that any default action normally taken by the implementation as a result of the event will not occur
- e.g. prevent the link above from following the URL, or prevent the form from submitting data

flashcards.front: When was the first version of DOM published, and why was it so important?
flashcards.back: DOM Level 1 was published as a W3C Recommendation in **1998** in order to standardize the different implementations of the Netscape Navigator and Internet Explorer known as **the browser wars**.

- get all `class="page"` elements on the page: 
	--------------------------------------
	const pageElems = document.querySelectorAll('.page');	
	--------------------------------------
- note that querySelectorAll returns a [NodeList](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/querySelectorAll)
	- it does not return an array
	- NodeList has `forEach`, `entries`, `keys`, and `values` 
	- but it does not have e.g. `map`, `find`, `filter`
	- you can convert a NodeList to an array so you can use `map`, `find`, `filter`
		- you can use `Array.from`
			----------------------
			const arrPageElems = Array.from(pageElems);
			----------------------
		- or you can use the ES6 spread operator
			--------------------------
			const arrPageElems = [...pageElems];
			--------------------------

submodules.title: 4.03 Asynchronous Programming
submodules.overview: The web is built on consuming data. In this sub module, you will dive into advanced JavaScript concepts such as `promises` and `async/await` through the usage of the browser's built in `fetch` API to consume data from 3rd party sources.
objectives: Identify the key characteristics of asynchronous processes
Use `promises` and `async/await` to facilitate an asynchronous workflow
Use `fetch` to retrieve data from an API and parse JSON objects
Use `localStorage` and `sessionStorage` to save data in the browser

flashcards.front: What is a JavaScript Promise?
flashcards.back: an object that represents the eventual completion or failure of an asynchronous operation and its resulting value

flashcards.front: What are the three possible states of a JavaScript Promise?
flashcards.back:
- fulfilled
- rejected
- pending

flashcards.front: What is callback hell?
flashcards.back:
- when you have numerous callbacks and each callback takes an argument that is a result of a previous callbacks
- in this manner, the code structure looks like a pyramid making it difficult to read and maintain

moreInfos.title: Stack Overflow: "In the below code, am I in callback hell?" / "Yes, you are in callback hell."

flashcards.front: What are three ways to avoid callback hell?
flashcards.back:
- break large functions with numerous nested callbacks into smaller functions to reduce the amount of nested code 
- use Promises with `.then()` syntax
- use Promises with `async/await` syntax

moreInfos.title: How to deal with nested callbacks and avoid callback hell

flashcards.front: Are promises uses for synchronous or asynchronous operations?
flashcards.back: asynchronous

flashcards.front: Does it make sense to use try/catch blocks in a promise?
flashcards.back: No, `try/catch` is redundant in promise chains and promise executor functions.  Any error thrown is automatically converted to a rejection of the promise you're supposed to return.

moreInfos.title: Stack Overflow: Cleancode: try/catch in Promise

flashcards.front: What is the difference between the HTTP methods POST and GET?
flashcards.back:
- GET is used to request data from a specified resource
- POST is used to send data to a server to create/update a resource

flashcards.front: What is CORS?
flashcards.back:
- Cross-Origin Resource Sharing
- a mechanism that allows restricted resources on a web page to be requested from another domain outside the domain from which the first resource was served
